awd_titl_txt: Active Assembly of Conducting Peptide Gels
awd_abstract_narration:
In living organisms, some structural components are assembled only when they are demanded for specific functions and then dissembled when they are no longer needed.  In this project, the research teams of Prof. Rein Ulijn at the City University of New York, and Prof. Allon Hochbaum at the University of California, Irvine, aim to understand how to control dynamic assembly processes and explore the feasibility of incorporating design concepts from the biological world into synthetic, non-living materials.   An important goal of this project is to develop new approaches to preparing electrically conducting assemblies that can change shape and make new connections in response to the environment or external stimuli, mimicking the dynamic behavior of biological materials.  The assemblies are potentially useful as materials for interfacing electronic devices with biological systems in biomedical applications.  This project provides interdisciplinary research training to graduate and undergraduate students.  The team inspires high school students, including underrepresented minority students, from the local area (Harlem, NY and Irvine, CA) with hands-on education and discovery programs.

With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry, the research team designs transient assemblies of peptide nanostructures, based on biocatalytic reactions that utilize chemical fuels to dynamically sustain the self-assembled state.  Activated amino acid methyl esters, with the energy stored in the ester bond, serve as fuels to provide the chemical energy required to drive assembly processes.  The amino acid part encodes the self-assembly of nanofibers that entangle to form a gel-phase material.  Modification of the peptide sequence enables modulation of the assembly dynamics and fiber stability.  Electronic functionality is introduced by incorporating semi-conducting organic molecules into the peptide building blocks.  Another aim of the project is to integrate the resulting materials with neuronal cells to investigate whether the behavior of neuronal cell can be influenced by electronic stimulation through these materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The differences between properties of living and non-living materials are often obvious to observe, in that the former are often dynamic and active, while the latter are usually static. The materials found in the living world therefore provide intriguing ideas for the design of materials that can change their properties in response to new situations by changing shape,  growing or changing their appearance. The reason for these differences lies in the way in which the molecule building blocks are organized within these materials. While the organization of building blocks is mostly fixed in synthetic materials, in living materials the organization is much more fluid, and it can the changed when required. In living organisms and inside their cells, these fluid-like materials properties are controlled by metabolism, networks of chemical reactions that are facilitated by specialized catalysts, called enzymes. In this project, we sought to develop materials that can be produced and analyzed in the laboratory, but can be regulated like living materials, by incorporating designs that make them sensitive to enzymes. 

In this context, the proposal focused on the development of materials that combine simple versions of biological molecules, peptides, that are enzyme-senstivie, with synthetic components, that provide functionality, with a focus on elements that conduct electricity or interact with light. The materials frequently look like long and thin fibers, and they can be formed or modified by enzymatic reactions, resulting in the control over the formation and breakdown of these fibers in space and time. We found that upon incorporation of synthetic functionial components, these materials have a number of interesting properties, including the ability to conduct electricity, the ability to catalyze reactions when exposed to light, and to self-degrade after use. We also demonstrated the interactions of these systems with living cells, and we found that the materials could assemble into larger objects in response to cell-produced enzymes, and that the materials in turn changed the behavior of the cells.

This research was predominantly conducted by graduate students. The research was strongly interdisciplinary and therefore provided unique opportunities for these students to learn about disciplines outside their own, each project including aspects of chemistry, materials science and biology. 

The broader impacts of the project were focused on interactions with the general public and high schools through hosting groups of students for tours and demonstrations of science concepts in our Illumination Space. Furthermore, graduate students were involved in research training of a diverse group of undergraduate students from within the City University of New York and University of California, Irvine. 

Specific outcomes include:

-       Demonstration of enzymatic build-up and breakdown of hybrid materials combining peptides and synthetic electronic components.

-       Demonstration of photocatalytic properties of nanomaterials produced by enzymatic-self-assembly.

-       Demonstration of new peptide modalities for enzyme triggered nanoparticle aggregation.

-       Demonstration of nanoparticle assembly and regulation of uptake in response to enzymes produced by biological cells.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Rein Ulijn
